To prepare safely and effectively for the opening of school in September, the Walton Central School District has added a second conference day during opening week. Conference days for staff will now be September 8-9.

The first day for students is Thursday, September 10.

One other change is at the high school where, to ensure each grade level will have one day in-person the first week, grades 9/11 will report on Thursday, September 10, and grades 10/12 will report on Friday, September 11. This is only for the first week. Starting the second week, the schedule will go as previously communicated.

If you have any questions, please contact your child’s building principal.

A school messenger message will be sent to families this evening as well.

School districts in the DCMO BOCES region have set tentative dates in June for the last day of the 2019-20 school year for students and staff.

County closures related to the COVID-19 pandemic; remaining snow/emergency days, state aid requirements, and each school district’s individual calendar helped determine “last day of school” dates for each district.

Because of these factors, there are slight differences from one district to another, and are subject to change pending further guidance from the Governor and/or the New York State Education Department.

The last day of school for the Walton Central School District for 2019-20 is June 17.

Our current plan for Walton CSD’s graduation ceremony, barring any changes in safety and gathering guidelines from the Governor and/or New York State, is June 13 (information has been announced and more will be coming), with the official graduation date still set as June 27.

Walton CSD senior Dylan Jacob recently earned Class C eighth-team all-state boys basketball honors from the New York State Sportswriters Association.

Jacob, a 5-11 guard, averaged 21.3 points per game, as well as eight rebounds, seven assists, and four steals.

During his tenure at Walton, Jacob amassed 1,277 points, 570 assists, and 344 steals. He also made 108 three-pointers.

Jacob reached the 1,000-point mark this past winter.

Congratulations, Dylan!

Walton CSD high school agriculture classes are holding “Ag in the Classroom” lessons for elementary students once a month at Townsend Elementary.

This is a student-led initiative that started last year.

The program is a possible through a grant received from New York State FFA. Walton was one of 91 schools that received this grant, which is about $2,500. The money is used for this program, as well as Ag Day later this spring.

Students write, plan, and teach a different lesson to each grade level. Each has an agricultural theme. Townsend students look forward to these multi-generational and interactive lessons. This program will continue through May and will lead up to Ag Day, where all elementary school students will get the chance to interact with animals, machinery, and other aspects of agriculture.

Walton CSD senior McKenzie Clough became the seventh player in school history to score her 1,000th varsity point!

Clough needed 13 points entering Walton’s Section Four tournament game at Greene. Last week, Clough earned her 1,000th varsity rebound.

Clough is the fourth girl in school history to reach the milestone, and the second player this year to reach the mark. Dylan Jacob eclipsed 1,000 points in January.

The others to score 1,000 points during their high school playing days at Walton are: Russell Mann (1955), Rick Lambrecht (1980), Janet Merrill (1989), Sybil Stanton (2007), Olivia Harby (2019), and Dylan Jacob (2020).

Congratulations, McKenzie!

This past fall, nearly 70 students from Walton CSD had the chance to see Hamilton on Broadway (see the story at: https://www.waltoncsd.org/protected/ArticleView.aspx?iid=5PYPI2&dasi=3GPIP).

As part of the grant for this experience, students had to do several educational assignments. One of those was to create their own play, song, or poem based on a topic or person they researched, regarding the founding era. Once the students had presented, each of the students voted which was best and submitted it to the Gilder Lehrman Institute.

In turn the institute chose 12 projects to perform on stage at the Richard Rogers Theater the morning of the show.

Walton’s submission was one of the 12 chosen, and Ellissa Beach and Grace Rhinehart had the opportunity to perform in front of nearly 1,300 students.

Below is a video, courtesy of the Gilder Lehrman Institute, of Beach and Rhinehart during their performance!
